title: Calculate your own body mass index
description: Find out how simple it is to calculate your BMI and the common BMI categories.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Prepositional phrases
description: Identify prepositional phrases and how to use them!

title: Common denominators
description: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

title: Spotting salty foods
description: Find out how much sodium is in some common foods and how you can maintain a low sodium diet.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Terminal prepositions
description: It's totally okay to end sentences with prepositions! David, Khan Academy's grammarian-in-chief, explains the history and the context behind this long-held grammar myth.

title: Adequacy of the lateral cervical spine X-ray
description: Dr. Mahadevan from Stanford School of Medicine explains adequacy for lateral cervical (neck) x-rays

title: Coordinating conjunctions
description: Coordinating conjunctions connect parts of sentences to each other. David explains how.

title: Assessing alignment of the lateral cervical spine (neck) X-ray
description: Dr. Mahadevan of Stanford Medical School shows Sal what misalignment in the neck could look like in an X-ray

title: Meet the conjunction
description: Learn to identify your new best friend, the conjunction.

title: Decomposing fractions
description: See that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.

title: BONUS: "FANBOYS," a mnemonic song
description:
"FANBOYS" is a mnemonic device you can use to help remember the coordinating conjunctions of English. Team Grammar made this video, figuring that we couldn't very well cover conjunctions without writing a song, now could we?

If you're moved to make your own version, send it our way at remix@khanacademy.org; we're excited to hear what you do!

title: Adding mixed numbers with like denominators
description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can add numbers....you can add fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can add mixed numbers! Watch.

title: Subtracting mixed numbers with like denominators
description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can subtract numbers....you can subtract fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can subtract mixed numbers! Watch.

title: Three ways to end a sentence
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, introduce the three ways to end a sentence: the period, the exclamation point, and the question mark.

title: Lines, line segments, and rays
description: Let's draw points, lines, line segments, and rays.  We'll also think about perpendicular and parallel lines and identify these in two-dimensional figures.  Common Core Standard: 4.G.A.1

title: Cervical spine protection in airway management (not a substitute for formal training)
description: Cervical Spine Protection in Airway Management.  This is for education only.  It is not a substitute for formal training or licensure.  Every effort has been made in preparing this video to provide accurate and up-to-date information which is in accord accepted standards and practice at the time of production.  We make no warranties on the information contained in the video because clinical standards are constantly changing through research and regulation.  We disclaim all liability for direct or consequential damages resulting from the use of material contained in this video.

title: Comparing decimals 3
description: Sal compares decimals like 45.675 and 45.645 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Coordinating conjunctions
description: Identify coordinating conjunctions and their functions.

title: Precocious puberty
description: At Stanford Medical School with Morgan Theis talking to  Dr. Laura Bachrach talking about precocious puberty

title: Childhood growth
description: Sal talks with Dr. Laura Bachrach about childhood growth

title: Subordinating conjunctions
description: Subordinating conjunctions join two parts of complex sentences––independent clauses to dependent clauses. David explains how.

title: Bacterial meningitis
description: Dr. Charles Prober discusses prudent prescribing of antibiotics in the context of bacterial meningitis with 4th year medical student Morgan Theis

title: Coordinating and subordinating conjunctions
description: Identify and use coordinating and subordinating conjunctions in sentences.

title: Ritual of the bedside exam
description: Dr. Abraham Verghese explains the ritual of the bedside exam

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

title: Correlative conjunctions
description: Correlative conjunctions work in pairs to connect parts of sentences. David teaches you how they do it!

title: Systemic thinking about cancer
description: Dr. David Agus discusses thinking systemically about cancer and other things

title: Inflammation
description: Dr. David Agus talks about inflammation (while Sal repeatedly misspells it with one "m")

title: Correlative conjunctions
description: Learn to recognize pairs of correlative conjunctions in sentences.

title: Beginning sentences with conjunctions
description: Is it okay to begin a sentence with a conjunction like "but" or "because"? Yes. David explains why.

title: Three ways to end a sentence
description: There are three types of terminal punctuation: a period, an exclamation point, and a question mark.

title: Meet the Comma
description: David and Paige introduce you to the superhero of the punctuation world: the comma! Practice this yourself on Khan Academy right now:

title: Meet the comma
description: Commas separate parts of sentences from each other, and they do so in many different ways.

title: Punctuating a list
description: Learn how to use commas to punctuate a written list of people, things, actions, or events.

title: Punctuating lists
description: Use commas to punctuate lists of things and actions!

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

title: Salutations and valedictions
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, talk about how to address and sign off on letters using commas!

title: Adding decimals
description: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

title: Commas in space and time
description: Learn how to use commas when writing addresses (in space) and dates (in time).

title: Salutations, valedictions, dates, and addresses
description: Commas are needed when starting or ending a letter/email, writing out dates, or writing out addresses.

title: Commas and introductory elements
description: In English, you use commas to separate introductory elements from the rest of a sentence. Find out how with David and Paige!

title: Commas and introductory elements
description: Basically, you can use commas at the beginning of sentences to set up an introduction.

title: Adding decimals: tenths
description: Add two numbers that are either whole numbers or written to the tenths place value.

title: More uses for commas
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, discuss tag questions, yes and no statements, and direct address -- all situations where the comma is super useful.

title: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

title: Linking function of the colon
description: KA grammarian Paige introduces an important piece of punctuation that helps link items in a sentence: the colon!

title: Introduction to semicolons
description: Learn to identify and use semicolons in sentences!

title: Adding decimals: hundredths
description: Add two numbers that are written to the ones, tenths, or hundredths place.

title: Commas in dialogue
description: “Today we’re going to talk about using commas in dialogue,” said David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians.

title: The colon as a separator
description: The colon can separate parts of a title, citations of religious texts, and the hour and minutes in the time of day. Paige explains how!

title: Commas in dialogue, tag questions, direct address, and yes-or-no responses
description: Find and use commas to set off dialogue, in tag questions, for direct address, and for yes-and-no responses.

title: Introduction to colons
description: Learn how to identify and use the colon in a sentence!

title: Subtracting decimals
description: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

title: Appositives
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, cover appositives and how to use commas along with them.

title: Appositives
description: We use appositives to redefine or clarify a noun phrase; test your knowledge in this exercise!

title: Introduction to the semicolon
description: Paige introduces a piece of punctuation called the semicolon; this punctuation can link closely related independent clauses together in a sentence.

title: BONUS: The Oxford comma
description: David and Paige tackle the great comma debate of our time: Oxford comma or no Oxford comma?

title: Adding and subtracting fractions word problems
description: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions.

title: Semicolons and complex lists
description: We use semicolons to punctuate a complex list, which is when list items contain commas. For example, “I visited Paris, France; Paris, Texas; and Paris, Illinois.” Paige explains.

title: Introduction to the apostrophe
description: David and Paige, KA’s resident grammarians, introduce a new piece of punctuation: the apostrophe!

title: Subtracting decimals: tenths
description: Complete subtraction problems where both numbers are written to the tenths place.

title: Using semicolons and commas
description: Identify when to use semicolons and commas in complex sentences.

title: Meet the apostrophe
description: Apostrophes have many important uses in the English language, and this exercise will give you an introduction to those uses!

title: Subtracting decimals: hundredths
description: Complete subtraction problems where both numbers are written to the hundredths place.

title: Introduction to contractions
description: Apostrophes are great at standing in for missing letters, allowing us to shorten words. Paige and David discuss contractions and the Principle of Least Effort.

title: Using colons and semicolons
description: Identify whether to use colons or semicolons in sentences!

title: Introduction to contractions
description: Apostrophes help shorten words by creating contractions. Learn how to spot them!

title: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions
description: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

title: Apostrophes and plurals
description: There is *one* extremely rare case in which we use apostrophes to make things plural. David and Paige, KA's resident grammarians, discuss this unusual case.

title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
description: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

title: Apostrophes and plurals
description: Apostrophes are generally not used to form English plurals, but there are a few exceptions.

title: Italics, underlines, and quotes
description: Learn how to use italics, underlines, and quotes when writing titles of books, movies, songs, etc.

title: Introduction to the possessive
description: Apostrophes can help show when something belongs to someone. Paige and David explain how!

title: Multiplication as scaling
description: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

title: Parentheses
description: Parentheses set off extra information (such as a writer's remarks, an interruption, or a reference) from the rest of a sentence. Learn how to use them in this video!

title: Multiplying decimals
description: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

title: Possession for words ending in “s”
description: Do words that end in "s" still need _'s_ to show possession? David and Paige explain!

title: Multiplying mixed numbers
description: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

title: Dividing decimals 1
description: Divide a whole number by a number written to the tenths or hundredths place.  Quotients are whole numbers.

title: Pronoun-antecedent agreement
description: Pronouns and their antecedents need to agree in number.

title: Dangling modifiers
description: A modifying word or phrase “dangles” when it doesn’t apply to the word it’s supposed to modify. Learn how to spot and fix this problem!

title: Reflecting points in the coordinate plane
description: Practice reflecting points across axes on the xy coordinate plane.

title: Frequently confused words: assorted
description: Can you identify when to correctly use these words that often get confused with other words?

title: Common expressions: easy
description: Can you identify which prepositions to use for these common expressions?

title: Common expressions: medium
description: Can you spot the correct prepositions to use in these conventional expressions?

title: Style!
description: Let's talk about style!  Learn to make your language swoop and sing; get a handle on etiquette; and crack open the secret of sarcasm and irony.

title: Area of trapezoids & composite figures
description: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

title: Introduction to the parenthesis
description: Parentheses are used to set off extra information from a sentence, show an interruption, or indicate a reference. Practice identifying their uses in this exercise!

title: Introduction to the possessive
description: Learn to use apostrophes to indicate possession, or ownership -- and when not to use them.

title: Multiplying fractions
description: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

title: Dashes
description: Dashes are like little actors—they can behave like colons, pairs of commas, or parentheses.  Learn how to use them in this video!

title: Advanced (plural) possession
description: Paige and David talk about using apostrophes to show that something belongs to multiple people.

title: Advanced (plural) possession
description: Possessive plurals have a complicated relationship with apostrophes, but this exercise is here to help you understand it!

title: Introduction to the dash
description: Dashes indicate interruptions, set off asides, and show interruptions in speech. Learn the different functions of dashes in this exercise.

title: Choosing between its and it’s
description: David and Paige explain the meaning of two English words that look and sound very similar but act very different: _its_ and _it's_.

title: Dashes and hyphens
description: Learn the uses of—and differences between—dashes and hyphens.

title: Choosing between its and it's
description: This is one of the most common slip-ups you can make in English! Let's give it a shot.

title: BONUS: History of the apostrophe
description: The apostrophe has a bizarre history, including being the name for something that's not really related to grammar at all. David, Paige, and special guest Jake explain.

title: Dividing decimals
description: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

title: BONUS: History of the possessive apostrophe
description: David, Paige, and Jake cover the fascinating history of the possessive apostrophe. Stay tuned for this bonus video!

title: Introduction to the ellipsis
description: The ellipsis is used to show a pause in speech or that part of a sentence has been removed.

title: Multiplying fractions word problems
description: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

title: Angle introduction
description: What is an angle and how do we label, measure and construct them? Great question. Luckily we have all your answers! To begin our journey towards understanding angles, we'll learn terms like vertex, acute, obtuse, circle arc, circumference, and protractor. These basic angle concepts will get you on the road to angle domination!

title: What is a sentence?
description: A sentence is a grammatically complete idea. All sentences have a noun or pronoun component called the subject, and a verb part called the predicate. David and Paige explore this division across several different example sentences.

title: Dividing decimals 2
description: Divide a whole number by a number written to the tenths or hundredths place.  Quotients may include decimals.

title: Three types of sentence
description: Three essential types of sentence are declarative sentences (which are statements), interrogative sentences (which are questions), and imperative sentences (which are orders). Join us as we give examples of each!

title: Declarative, interrogative, and imperative sentences
description: Can you tell whether or not a sentence is a statement, a question, or an order? Let's find out!

title: Fractions as division
description: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

title: Exclamations
description: An exclamation is a sentence that expresses great emotion! David and Paige covered declarative, interrogative, and imperative sentences; now they tackle a fourth type of sentence that ends in an exclamation mark. Find out more!

title: Dangling modifiers
description: A modifying word or phrase is said to ‘dangle’ when it doesn’t affect the word it’s supposed to modify.

title: Quadrilaterals on the coordinate plane
description: Math problems that test your understanding of Quadrilateral and points on the coordinate plane

title: Bare/bear, allowed/aloud, advice/advise, and break/brake
description: We've got a bunch going all at once, here: learn to tell the differences between these eight frequently-confused words.

title: Common expressions
description: Also known as idioms, these phrases and expressions are difficult to translate into other languages.  How well do you know your common English expressions?

title: Perimeter
description: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land? No? Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case. You'll learn what perimeter is and how to calculate it.

title: Common expressions: hard
description: Can you spot the correct prepositions to use in these conventional expressions?

title: Drawing polygons in the coordinate plane
description: Practice drawing shapes on the coordinate plane.

title: Where did agriculture come from?
description: Test your knowledge of early agriculture!

title: Area of trapezoids
description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Area of trapezoids
description: Practice finding the areas of trapezoids.

title: Simple and compound sentences
description: A simple sentence contains one independent clause. A compound sentence contains more than one! Put another way: a simple sentence contains a subject and a predicate, but a compound sentence contains more than one subject and more than one predicate.

title: Dividing unit fractions and whole numbers
description: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

title: Simple and compound sentences
description: Identify which sentences are simple and which are compound

title: Rearranging simple and compound sentences
description: Identify and arrange simple and compound sentences.

title: Complex sentences
description: Complex sentences are simple sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them. Paige and Rosie explain how to spot them and use them in this video.

title: Compound-complex sentences
description: Compound-complex sentences are compound sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them. Paige and Rosie explain how to spot and use them.

title: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

title: Complex and compound-complex sentences
description: Complex sentences are simple sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them. Compound-complex sentences are compound sentences with dependent or subordinate clauses added to them.

title: Angles in circles
description: Learn how to measure angles using a circle protractor and solve word problems about angles as part of a circle.

title: Subjects and predicates
description: A subject is the noun or pronoun-based part of a sentence, and a predicate is the verb-based part that the subject performs. Let’s explore how that works in context.

title: Properties of shapes
description: Learn how different shapes have different numbers of corners, different side lengths, and so on. Use these properties to help you recognize shapes.

title: Identifying subject and predicate
description: Identify subject and predicate as parts of the sentences.

title: Triangles
description: Triangles can be classified in different ways. In this tutorial, we'll learn about scalene, isosceles, equilateral, acute, right, and obtuse triangles.

title: Angles between intersecting lines
description: This tutorial introduces us to angles.  It includes how we measure them, how angles relate to each other and properties of angles created from various types of intersecting lines.  Mr. Angle is actually far more fun than you might initially presume him to be.

title: Reflecting points in the coordinate plane
description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself, but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite side of the axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Area of rectangles
description: Transition from counting unit squares to multiplying side length to find area.  Measure side lengths with a ruler to find area.  Find area of rectangles by multiplying side lengths.  Find a missing side length of a rectangle when given the other side length and area.

title: Less versus fewer
description: How do you know when to use "less" and "fewer" when describing things?

title: Volume of rectangular prisms
description: Welcome to the 3rd dimension! [cue spooky music] This tutorial explains how to find volume.

title: Subject, direct object, and indirect object
description: A subject is the noun phrase that drives the action of a sentence; in the sentence “Jake ate cereal,” Jake is the subject. The direct object is the thing that the subject acts upon, so in that last sentence, “cereal” is the direct object; it’s the thing Jake ate. An indirect object is an optional part of a sentence; it’s the recipient of an action. In the sentence “Jake gave me some cereal,” the word “me” is the indirect object; I’m the person who got cereal from Jake.

title: Dividing fractions word problems
description: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

title: Identifying subject, direct object, and indirect object
description: Learn to identify the subject and direct/indirect objects of sentences.

title: Angle types
description: Now that we know what angles are, let's dig a bit deeper and classify them and understand their properties better. Acute, obtuse, right, adjacent--all are angles that we will be become familiar with.

title: Phrases and clauses
description: A phrase is any collection of words that behaves like a part of speech, like a noun phrase (“my brother Stu”), an adjectival phrase (“in a different shade of blue”), or an adverbial phrase (“with elegance and tact”). A clause is any noun phrase plus a verb; they can be sentences, but they don’t always have to be. You’ll see!

title: Quadrilaterals
description: Not all things with four sides and 90 degree angles are squares or rectangles! Sometimes the angles in these 4-sided shapes are less than (or greater than) 90 degrees, causing them to have a slightly odd shape. These are called quadrilaterals and come in a few different varieties. In this tutorial, you'll learn about them.

title: Introduction to phrases and clauses
description: Learn to spot the differences between phrases and clauses.

title: Dependent and independent clauses
description: An independent clause is a sentence that has a subject and a verb and requires no extra information to understand. Dependent clauses, which start with subordinating conjunctions such as "while," "that," or "unless," give background information but cannot stand on their own as sentences.

title: Subject-verb agreement
description: Agreement is the art of making sure that sentence parts agree with one another; you want to make sure that your subjects and verbs match up.

title: Dependent and independent clauses
description: Independent clauses can be sentences. Dependent clauses can’t! Let’s take a deeper dive into what that looks like in this exercise.

title: Subject-verb agreement
description: Agreement is the art of making sure that sentence parts connect with one another.

title: Phrase and clause placement
description: Choose the best placement for the phrase or clause in the sentences provided!

title: Pronoun-antecedent agreement
description: An antecedent is “the thing that came before”. When you use a pronoun, it’s standing in for a word you used previously—that’s the antecedent. Join us as we demonstrate how to make sure that your pronouns and antecedents match up with one another: that’s called agreement!

title: Relative clauses
description: A relative pronoun is a word like “that” or “which” or “who”, so a relative clause is a clause that begins with a relative pronoun. In the sentence “The dragon who breathed blue fire has retired,” “who breathed blue fire” is a relative clause. Learn more about these constructions by watching the video!

title: Relative clauses
description: We use relative pronouns to connect descriptive phrases to nouns, creating a relative clause. Test your knowledge of how they work!

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

title: Recognizing fragments
description: A sentence fragment is a chunk of language that hasn’t made it all the way to being a working sentence; it might be missing a verb, or there might not be a subject. Learn how to turn a fragment into a sentence in this video!

title: Coordinate plane: quadrant 1
description: How can we communicate exactly where something is in two dimensions?  In this tutorial, we cover the basics of the coordinate plane and graphing points.

title: Recognizing fragments
description: A fragment is a part of a sentence, but can’t be a sentence on its own.

title: Run-ons and comma splices
description: A run-on sentence doesn’t separate any of its independent clauses with the punctuation that it needs, and a comma splice incorrectly separates two independent clauses with a comma, instead of a comma-and-coordinating-conjunction.

title: Recognizing run-ons and comma splices
description: Run-on sentences and comma splices happen when a writer isn’t careful with commas. Let’s see how you do!

title: Vertical angles review
description: Review the basics of vertical angles, and try some practice problems.

title: Parallel structure
description: Parallel structure isn’t a set rule, but more of a stylistic choice: it helps sentence elements maintain a pattern. This is a very special episode because it’s Paige’s last video with us as a KA intern! We will miss having Paige as a contributor to the Grammar Team.

title: Coordinate plane: 4 quadrants
description: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

title: Parallel structure
description: Parallel structure is a stylistic choice to make verbs in a sentence maintain a pattern.

title: Classifying geometric shapes
description: Practice classifying geometric shapes.

title: Affect and effect
description: TL;DW: affect's a verb and effect's a noun. But there's a little more to it than that.

title: Triangle angles
description:
Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.A.5

title: Frequently confused words: affect/effect
description: Do you know when to use “affect” and when to use “effect”?

title: Count unit squares to find area
description: Find area of shapes by counting unit squares.  Some shapes will require combining partial square units to find area.  Create rectangles with a given area by covering unit squares.

title: Hear/here and accept/except
description: Learn to tell when to use "hear" instead of "here" and vice versa; you'll learn how to do the same with "accept" and "except".

title: Frequently confused words: here-hear
description: Can you identify the difference between the words “here” and “hear”?

title: There, their, and they're
description: This is one of the most frequently-confused trios in the English language. Follow along, and learn to suss out the differences between these three words.

title: Frequently confused words: there-their-they're
description: Do you know when to use “there”, “their”, and “they’re”?

title: Reflecting points on coordinate plane
description: Learn to reflect points on a coordinate plane across both axes and the origin.

title: To, two, and too
description: Another troublesome triad, "to", "two", and "too".  Let's set these` frequently-confused words straight!

title: Frequently confused words: too-to-two
description: Can you tell the difference between the words “to,” “two,” and “too”?

title: Compliment/complement and desert/dessert
description: How do you tell the difference between "compliment" and "complement", "desert" and "dessert"? We'll show you!

title: Geometric solids (3D shapes)
description: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

title: The Sound of Language: Alliteration, Assonance, and Onomatopoeia
description: This video will teach you all about the different ways you can use the sound of words for effect. Alliteration is when you use a bunch of similar consonants in a row; assonance is when you use a bunch of similar vowel sounds in a row; onomatopoeia is basically sound effects. You'll see.

title: The sound of language
description: Can you spot writers’ use of alliteration, assonance, and onomatopoeia that add sound effects to their language?

title: The scale of formality
description: How formal or informal should you be when you write or speak? Let's dive into that!

title: Under- and overstatement
description: This is, bar none, the greatest video Khan Academy has ever made, although I may be slightly overstating that. Learn how to master this style by following along.

title: The origin of humans and early human societies
description: The origin of humans and early human societies, a tutorial in Technological and environmental transformations (to c. 600 BCE), the first period in the AP World History course.

title: Irony
description: Irony, puns, and sarcasm are some of the toughest concepts in English.  This video attempts to explain all three.

title: Area of parallelograms
description: Understand the formula for the area of a parallelogram.

title: Style and technique
description: Use context to figure out how to use language appropriately–formality, irony, understatement, and overstatement.

title: Knowing prehistory
description: Test your knowledge of archaeological terms!

title: Volume with fractions
description: Finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths

title: Where did humans come from?
description: Test your knowledge of early hominids and paleolithic migration

title: Pythagorean theorem
description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

Common Core Standards: 8.G.B.7, 8.G.B.8

title: Paleolithic societies
description: Paleolithic literally means “Old Stone [Age],” but the Paleolithic era more generally refers to a time in human history when foraging, hunting, and fishing were the primary means of obtaining food.

title: Paleolithic life
description: Test your knowledge of paleolithic life!

title: Surface area
description: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

title: The Neolithic Revolution and the birth of agriculture
description: a tutorial in Technological and environmental transformations (to c. 600 BCE), the first period in the AP World History course.

title: Pythagorean theorem application
description: Apply the Pythagorean theorem to area and perimeter, 3D figures, and real world problems.

title: Why did human societies get more complex?
description: Test your knowledge of what contributed to the growing complexity of human societies!

title: Area of kites
description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia
description: Often referred to as the "cradle of civilization", we have some of our first major civilizations emerge along the Tigris and Euphrates rivers as early as 6000 years ago.

title: Pythagorean theorem challenge
description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using the Pythagorean Theorem!

title: Pythagorean theorem and distance between points
description: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between points on a coordinate plane and the length of diagonal lines on a coordinate plane.

title: Finding distance with Pythagorean theorem
description: Sal finds the distance between two points with the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Area and circumference of circles
description: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres
description: Let's see how to find the volumes of cylinders, spheres and other three dimensional shapes.

title: Mesopotamia
description: Test your knowledge of ancient Mesopotamian civilization!

title: The Greek polis
description: Test your knowledge of the history of Greek city-states!

title: Translations
description: Learn about transformations and how to perform them.

title: Ancient Americas
description: Thousands of years before the Europeans began to colonize the Americas, many, complex civilizations had risen on these two continents.

title: Identity property of 0
description: Sal shows how any number plus 0 is the original number.

title: Ides of March spark a civil war
description: The power vacuum left by Caesar begins a scramble for power between Octavian and Marc Antony.

title: Inverse property of multiplication
description: Simple idea that multiplying by a number's multiplicative inverse gets you back to one. 5 × 1/5 = 1

title: Congruence and similarity
description: Learn about congruence and similarity, specifically as they relate to transformations.  Learn to dilate shapes.

title: Key concepts: the spread of Islam
description: Check your understanding of the first Islamic empires.

title: State building: Rise of Chinese dynasties
description: Answer passage-based questions about Emperor Qin Shi Huang.

title: Sunni and Shia Islam
description: A high-level overview of two major types of Islam: Sunni and Shia.

title: Ancient Egypt
description: When we think of the ancient world, the Egyptian pyramids and hieroglyphics come to mind, and for good reason. Ancient Egypt is one of the first and longest last significant civilizations that we currently know of. We will also discuss one of their key rivals, the Hittites.

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

Common Core Standard: 8.G.B.6

title: Egypt
description: Test your knowledge of ancient Egypt!

title: Volume formulas review
description: Review the formulas for the volume of prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres.

title: Hittites
description: Test your knowledge of the Hittite empire!

title: Ancient art and artifacts
description: This tutorial includes the Ancient Near East, and Ancient Greece and Rome.

title: Ancient Persia
description: An overview of the ancient Persian empire, with focus on the Achaemenid Empire started by Cyrus the Great and ended by Alexander the Great.

title: Place value
description: In this tutorial we'll learn about place value.  This is key to better understanding what we're really doing when we count, carry, regroup, multiply, and divide with multi-digit numbers.

title: Ancient India
description: Over 4000 years ago, the Indus Valley Civilization (Harappan) was one of the few technologically sophisticated civilizations on the plant. Their society declined for unknown reasons, but it roughly coincides with the migration of Indo-Aryans from the north west which starts the Vedic Period.

title: Line of symmetry
description: A line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure is a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. In this tutorial, we'll identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

title: The Achaemenid Empire
description: How well do you know the Achaemenid Empire? Let's do a quick little check-up before we move on.

title: Indus Valley civilization
description: Test your knowledge of the Indus Valley civilization!

title: State-building: The Persian Empire
description: Let's analyze some historical documents that pertain to the Persian Empire, its great cities, and its expansion.

title: Classical Greece
description: Greece fights off the Persians and enters its Golden Era, only to breakdown into the Peloponnesian war and eventual conquest by the Macedonians.

title: Shang China
description: The Shang Dynasty is the earliest dynasty for which there is a strong historical record in China. The Xia Dynasty purportedly predates it, but historians debate its historicity.

title: Transformations intro
description: Identify transformations, including translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

title: State-building: the Greek polis
description: Answer questions based on a passage relating to Greek-city states.

title: Ancient China
description: Test your knowledge of Ancient Chinese empires!

title: Rounding whole numbers
description:
If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs?  Probably not.  All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs).

In this tutorial, we'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers.  Very useful when we might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.

title: Ancient Mesoamerica
description: Test your knowledge of ancient Mesoamerica!

title: Classical Greek society
description: Test your knowledge of ancient Greek culture and society!

title: ClassicalGreek culture and society
description: Answer questions based on a passage about Greek culture and society.

title: Ancient Andes
description: Test your knowledge of the ancient Andean civilizations!

title: Human innovation and the environment
description:
Where do we think humans come from?  How and why have we developed as a species.  This tutorial attempts to give an overview of these truly fundamental questions.

From human evolution (which is covered in more depth in the biology playlist) to the development of agriculture, this tutorial will give you an appreciation of where we've been (and maybe where we're going).

title: Regrouping whole numbers
description: Regrouping involves taking value from one place and giving it to another.  It is a great way to make sure you understand place value.  It is also super useful when subtracting multi-digit numbers (the process is often called "borrowing" even though you never really "pay back" the value taken from one place and given to another).

title: Prelude to the Peloponnesian War
description: Tensions rise between Athens and Sparta. This leads to the Peloponnesian War.

title: The rise and fall of empires
description: Comparing the rise and fall of empires

title: Order of operations
description: If you have the expression "3 + 4 x 5", do you add the 3 to the 4 first or multiply the 4 and 5 first?  To clear up confusion here, the math world has defined which operation should get priority over others.  This is super important.  You won't really be able to do any involved math if you don't get this clear.  But don't worry, this tutorial has your back.

title: Rotate points
description: Given a point and a definition of a rotation, plot the rotation on a coordinate plane or identify the coordinates of the rotated point.

title: Rise and fall of empires
description: Test your knowledge on the rise and fall of empires!

title: Byzantine Empire
description: An overview of the history of the Byzantine Empire. Continuity and change after the fall of Rome.

title: Identity property of 1
description: The identity property of 1 says that any number multiplied by 1 keeps its identity. In other words, any number multiplied by 1 stays the same. The reason the number stays the same is because multiplying by 1 means we have 1 copy of the number. For example, 32x1=32.

title: Key concepts: Peasant revolts
description: Check your knowledge on the history of peasant revolts!

title: Inverse property of addition
description: The simple idea that a number plus its negative is 0

title: Origins of Islam
description: An overview of the origins of Islam, including the life of Muhammad, the Hijra to Medina, and the conversion of Mecca.

title: Arithmetic properties
description:
2 + 3 = 3 + 2, 6 x 4 = 4 x 6.  Adding zero to a number does not change the number.  Likewise, multiplying a number by 1 does not change it.

You may already know these things from working through other tutorials, but some people (not us) like to give these properties names that sound far more complicated than the property themselves.  This tutorial (which we're not a fan of), is here just in case you're asked to identify the "Commutative Law of Multiplication".   We believe the important thing isn't the fancy label, but the underlying idea (which isn't that fancy).

title: Empire of Alexander the Great
description: A survey of the Macedonian conquests of Greece and Persia.

title: Determine rotations
description: Given a figure on the coordinate plane and a center of a rotation, find the angle for the rotation that maps one figure to the other.

title: Philip of Macedon unifies Greece
description: How did Philip of Macedon unify Greece? Sal discusses his rise to power, the League of Corinth, and the rise of Alexander the Great.

title: Guided practice: continuity and change in the Byzantine Empire
description: Read about the continuities and changes between the Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire and complete guided practice.

title: Commutative law of addition
description: Commutative Law of Addition

title: Reflections
description: Learn about reflections and how to perform them.

title: Commutative law of multiplication
description: Commutative Law of Multiplication

title: Key concepts: the Byzantine Empire
description: Check your knowledge of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Rise of Rome
description: Starting as a small kingdom city-state on the Italian peninsula before the 8th century BCE, Rome grows first into a republic that dominates the Mediterranean and Europe and lays the foundation for Western Civilization.

title: European Middle Ages: feudalism and serfdom
description: An overview of the history of European serfdom in the Medieval period

title: Associative law of addition
description: Associative Law of Addition

title: Associative law of multiplication
description: Associative Law of Multiplication

title: Punic Wars between Rome and Carthage
description: Three Punic Wars between Rome and Carthage mark the end of the Carthaginian (Punic) Empire and leave the Roman Republic dominant in the Mediterranean.

title: Key Concepts: Serfdom
description: Let's dig into the history of unfree agriculture in post-Carolingian Europe.

title: Roman Republic
description: Test your knowledge on the Roman Republic!

title: Properties & definitions of transformations
description: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

title: From Roman Republic to Roman Empire
description: After nearly 500 years as a Republic, Rome officially becomes an empire under Augustus.

title: Dilations
description:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

title: Roman empire
description: Test your knowledge on the Roman empire!

title: Distributive property
description: The distributive property is an idea that shows up over and over again in mathematics.  It is the idea that 5 x (3 + 4) = (5 x 3) + (5 x 4).  If that last statement made complete sense, no need to watch this tutorial.  If it didn't or you don't know why it's true, then this tutorial might be a good way to pass the time :)

title: State building: Roman empire
description: Answer questions about the Roman empire based on a passage.

title: The Roman Empire
description: A survey of the Roman Empire from Augustus and Pax Romana to the fall of the Western Roman Empire 500 years later.

title: Context of pre-Islamic Arabia
description: Muhammad spreads revelations rejecting the idol worship of Mecca and urged his followers to submit to God, forming a religious community that became the Islamic faith.

title: Emperors of Pax Romana
description: Starting with the reign of Augustus and ending with the reign of Marcus Aurelius, the Pax Romana is a relatively stable 200 year period. The first five emperors are of the Julio-Claudia Dynasty. The last five of the Pax Romana are considered the "good" emperors by Machiavelli.

title: Key concepts: The origins of Islam
description: Test your knowledge of the origins of Islam!

title: Ara Pacis
description: Ara Pacis Augustae (Altar of Augustan Peace), 13-9 B.C.E.Speakers: Dr. Beth Harris & Dr. Steven Zucker

title: Dilations: center
description: Determining the center of dilation, given a figure and its image under a dilation.

title: Distributive property exercise examples
description: You'll be a pro applying the distributive property once you've solved these exercise examples with us.

title: Spread of Islam
description: As people traveled and traded across the world, Islam spread to those new places.

title: Dilations: center
description: Given a figure and its image under a dilation, determine the dilation's center point.

title: Ancient and Imperial China
description: For over 3500 years, China has had a relatively continuous civilization with long-lasting dynasties. In this tutorial, we will explore some of the most significant of these early dynasties, from the Zhou to the Qin to the Han.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
description: More numbers than you probably imagine can be represented as the ratio of two integers.  We call these rational numbers. But there are also really amazing numbers that can't.  As you can guess, we call them irrational numbers.

title: Rise of Chinese dynasties
description: Test your knowledge on the Zhou, Qin, and Han dynasties!

title: Philosophies of the Warring States Period
description: Let's review! What do you know about Confucianism, Legalism, and Daoism?

title: Golden Age of Islam
description: An overview of the Golden Age of Islam and the discoveries and re-discoveries of knowledge in Baghdad during this time.

title: Legalism and Daoism
description: Let's revisit that article from earlier and dive into Legalism and Daoism.

title: Early Judaism
description: Judaism is the basis of the religious beliefs of roughly half the world's population (Jews, Christians and Muslims). In this tutorial, we will explore the significant biblical and historical events.

title: Key concepts: golden age of Islam
description: Test your knowledge on the golden age of Islam!

title: Divisibility tests
description: Whether you are trying to impress your dog's friends (who are obsessed with figuring out number divisibility) or quickly factor a number, it can be very useful to tell whether a number is divisible by another.  This tutorial walks through some of the more standard divisibility methods and describes why they work.

title: Seeing America (Art that brings American history to life)
description: Art that brings American history to life

title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10
description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests.

title: ARCHES (At Risk Cultural Heritage Education Series)
Recognizing divisibility
description: Recognizing Divisibility.

title: Early Christianity
description: Christianity starts as a Jewish sect on the periphery of the Roman Empire. Despite being actively persecuted, the religion grows through the Empire, eventually becoming the official state religion.

title: Creating & conserving
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Learn how the ancient Greeks fired their ceramics, how renaissance artists created luminous oil paintings and the techniques developed by modern masters. Visit a museum and see what a conservator sees.

title: The why of the 3 divisibility rule
description: Why you can add the digits to see if something is divisible by 3

title: The why of the 9 divisibility rule
description: Why you can test divisibility by 9 by just adding the digits

title: The Crusades
description: What were the Crusades? Why did people go on them? What were the long-term impacts?

title: Spanish and Portuguese Empires
description: The Spanish and Portuguese were the first Europeans to build global empires.

title: Key concepts: Song China
description: Check your knowledge on the history of Song China!

title: Environment and trade
description: Environments had profound impacts on the ways people could conduct trade.

title: Factors and multiples
description: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!

title: Context: Judaism and Christianity
description: Answer passage-based and map-based questions about Christianity in the Roman Empire.

title: Scientific Revolution and Enlightenment
description: Copernicus challenging the notion that Earth is the center of the Universe is usually cited as the beginning of the Scientific Revolution. A time in which brave thinkers challenged the status quo based on evidence and logic. The period is considered to culminate with Newton's _Principia_. The Enlightenment emerges out of the ideas of the Scientific Revolution as philosophers begin to challenge traditional thinking in politics and human rights.

title: Technology and cultural transfers during the Crusades
description: Check your knowledge of technology and cultural transfers during the Crusades!

title: Early Americas
description: From the Mayans to the Teotihuacans in Mesoamerica to the Chavin, Nazca, Moche, Huari and Tiwanaku in the Andes, 600 BCE - 600 CE represents the rise (and fall) of many significant civilizations and cultures.

title: Mughal rule in India
description: After over three hundred years rule over North India, the Muslim Delhi Sultanate is overthrown by the Central Asian ruler Babar (who is descended from both Timur and Genghis Khan). He starts the Mughal Dynasty ("Mughal" is the Persian word for Mongol) that brings a further Persian influence to North India. As we enter the 18th century, Mughal power declines and we see the entrance of the British into Indian affairs.

title: The Mongols
description: In the thirteenth century, the Mongols expanded rapidly out of their homeland in the Asian steppes to become the largest contiguous land empire in history.

title: Sikhism
description: Guru Nanak begins a movement focused on devotional love of God. It develops in a context of emerging Mughal rule. Forged by bouts of persecution by the Mughal Emperors, it develops a martial culture with the goal of fighting oppression.

title: Prime numbers
description: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.

title: Empires in India
description: As we transition from the end of the Vedic Period, we enter into a time of the first significant empire formation in India. Both the Maurya and Gupta empires will have lasting impact not only on India, but the world.

title: The Protestant Reformation
description: In 1517 a German theologian and monk, Martin Luther, challenged the authority of the Pope and sparked the Protestant Reformation. His ideas spread quickly, thanks in part to the printing press. By challenging the power of the Church, and asserting the authority of individual conscience (it was increasingly possible for people to read the bible in the language that they spoke), the Reformation laid the foundation for the value that modern culture places on the individual.

title: Introduction to the Protestant Reformation: Setting the stage
description: What was Western Europe like before the Protestant Reformation? Learn about the influence of the Catholic church and the issues that led a monk named Martin Luther to demand reform.

title: Empires in India
description: Before we go further, let's make sure you've got a handle on some of the key concepts surrounding the Maurya and Gupta empires.

title: Introduction to the Protestant Reformation: Martin Luther
description: Learn about the life of Martin Luther and his dispute with the Catholic church.

title: Introduction to the Protestant Reformation: Varieties of Protestantism
description: Learn about the varieties of Protestant religion that emerged from the Reformation.

title: Prime factorization
description: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!

title: Key concepts: Hinduism and Buddhism
description: Check your knowledge on Hinduism and Buddhism in Indian culture!

title: Introduction to the Protestant Reformation: The Counter-Reformation
description: Learn about the Catholic response to the Protestant Reformation.

title: Medieval Japan
description: In the post-classical period, Japan was united by common language, culture, and economic structures, but government was decentralized.

title: Prime factorization
description: Prime Factorization

title: Indian cultures: focus on Hinduism and Buddhism
description: Answer passage-based questions about Hinduism and Buddhism.

title: Protestant Reformation
description: Test your comprehension of the political and religious issues of the Reformation and Counter-Reformation.

title: Early Hinduism
description: Often considered the world's oldest living religion, Hinduism is still practiced by over 1 billion people despite having roots in the Vedic Period and the Indus Valley Civilization. It is also one of the most diverse and open religions.

title: Maya, Aztec, and Inca
description: An overview of the Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations.

title: Common divisibility examples
description: Common Divisibility Examples

title: Cranach, Law and Gospel
description: Test your knowledge.

title: Least common multiple
description: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.

title: Key concepts: Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations
description: Check your knowledge on the history of Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations!

title: The Russian Empire
description: From its medieval, Nordic-Slav roots as the 'land of Rus', Russia will eventually break free of Mongol control and emerge as a significant empire in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia.

title: Topic C: Lesson 12: Types of statistical studies
Early Buddhism
description: From the life of Siddartha Gautama Buddha to his teachings and modern schools of Buddhism.

title: Greatest common factor
description: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!

title: Key Concepts: environment and trade
description: Check your knowledge on environment and trade during the Viking Age!

title: Representing data
description: Learn about different ways to represent and display data.

title: Human migration
description: Various factors affect whether people choose to leave their homes and make new lives. We will explore the history and impacts of migration.

title: Stem and leaf plots
description: Learn how to read and interpret stem-and-leaf plots.

title: Causes and effects of human migration
description: Migration is the movement of people from one place to another with the intent to settle. Learn more about why it was important!

title: Stem-and-leaf plots
description: A stem and leaf is a table used to display data. The 'stem' is on the left displays the first digit or digits. The 'leaf' is on the right and displays the last digit. For example, 543 and 548 can be displayed together on a stem and leaf as 54 | 3,8.

title: Key concepts: Human Migration
description: Test your knowledge of what contributes to human migrations!

title: First things first
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. New to art? This is a good place to start. Art gives us access to the way people at different moments in history have understood the world. Jump in and explore!

title: Syncretism
description: Test your knowledge on syncretism!

title: Women and families
description: This section offers an exploration of how women and families lived in different places in history.

title: Development of new trading cities
description: As trade routes expanded, so did major trading cities such as Hangzhou, Malacca, and Timbuktu

title: Tools for understanding art
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory.

title: Picture graphs, bar graphs, and histograms
description: Read and interpret picture graphs, bar graphs and histograms.  Also, make some graphs of your own!

title: Art 1010
description: Art 1010 is a short series of fun (and funny) animations created for the Utah System of Higher Education that introduce the history of Western art.

title: Topic C: Lessons 21-23: Transforming vectors with matrices
Reading pictographs
description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.

title: Key concepts: development of new trading cities
description: Check your knowledge on trading cities!

title: Women and families in classical societies
description: Test your knowledge about women's lives in Imperial Rome and Han China!

title: Cultural interactions along trade routes
description: We'll look at how the Srivijaya Empire, an empire on the Malay Peninsula lasting from the seventh to the twelfth century, was shaped by its interactions with its chief trading partners.

title: American Revolution
description: The United States is the first major nation to break the chains of colonialism and rule by a king, based on ideas of the Enlightenment. It sets the stage for the French Revolution and multiple revolution in the early 19th century throughout the Americas. It can be viewed in the context of a broader struggle between England and France.

title: The Silk Road
description: Test your knowledge on the history of the Silk Road!

title: Reading bar graphs
description: Reading Bar Graphs.

title: Key concepts: The Srivijaya Empire
description: Check your knowledge on the history of the Srivijaya Empire!

title: Interpreting bar graphs: alligators
description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem using a bar graph.

title: Survey of second-wave civilizations
description: This tutorial attempts to give a very high level view of the civilizations that emerge in the period around 600 BCE.

title: Birth of the US Constitution
description: In this video, Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson talks to Sal about  the Declaration of Independence.

title: Survey from Neo Babylonians to Persians
description: Let's continue our fast survey of ancient history, with references to the stories from the Old Testament.

title: Development of financial institutions
description: Financial institutions, specifically banks, developed as a result of cross-cultural interactions and the need to pay for trade and war.

title: Histograms
description: Histograms let you see the frequency distribution of a data set. Learn how and when to use histograms to visualize data.

title: French Revolution
description:
"Let them eat cake!"  "No, how about we cut your head off instead!"  

The French Revolution was ugly, bloody and idealistic.  This tutorial covers the beginning of the end of the Bourbon rule (actually doesn't really go away for 60 years) and birth of France as a Republic (which will really take about 80 years).

title: Ancient Greeks and Persians
description: Sal provides an overview of the Greco-Persian Wars and the Peloponnesian War.

title: French Revolution (part 2)
description: Royals try to escape. Champ De Mars Massacre. Declaration of Pillnitz. Movement towards becoming a Republic.

title: Rome becomes dominant
description: Continuing our survey of ancient history. End with a dominant Rome and the life of Jesus.

title: Reading pie graphs (circle graphs)
description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)

title: Key concepts: financial institutions
description: Check your knowledge of the history of banking!

title: Frequency tables and dot plots
description: A dot plot is like a bar chart, but it displays data using dots (not bars). And a frequency table is like a dot plot, but it displays data in a simple table (not a fancy diagram).

title: French Revolution (part 3) - Reign of Terror
description: The Reign of Terror

title: French Revolution (part 4) - The Rise of Napoleon Bonaparte
description: The rise of Napoleon Bonaparte

title: Disease and demography
description: How did the plague spread? We'll cover the history of the plague in Europe.

title: Napoleon Bonaparte
description:
A man with such a huge "Napoleonic complex", that they named it after him.  A military genius with a ginormous ego, some people consider him a hero or a tyrant or both.

France has successfully overthrown Louis XVI in 1789.  It has gone through a many-year period of bloodshed and instability.  The monarch's of Europe are not happy about this "overthrow-your-king" business.  A 5'6'' Corsican establishes himself as a strong military tactician during the wars with other European powers and soon comes to power in France.

This tutorial covers the rise and fall of one of the most famous men in all of history: Napoleon Bonaparte (Napoleon I).

title: Key concepts: disease and demography
description: Check your knowledge on disease and demography!

title: Napoleon and the Wars of the First and Second Coalitions
description: Overview of the first two coalitions against France and Napoleon's roles in them.

title: Area of rectangles
description: Area is how we thinking about how much space something takes in two dimensions such as comparing how much land one property takes up versus another.  In this tutorial, we'll take a conceptual look at how area is actually measured (especially for rectangles).

title: Misleading line graphs
description: Misleading Line Graphs

title: Napoleon and the War of the Third Coalition
description: Napoleon leads France to become the dominant power in Europe.  Napoleon I becomes Emperor of France.

title: Social institutions in the Islamic world
description: An overview of Medieval Muslim societies.

title: Napoleon and the War of the Fourth Coalition
description: Napoleon takes on Prussia and Russia and wins again

title: Number patterns
description: Let's explore how numbers can grow in different ways and use what we learn to figure out where they can go.  We think you'll find this tutorial on number patterns more fun that you do :)

title: Key concepts: Medieval Muslim Societies
description: Check your understanding of medieval Muslim societies!

title: Napoleon's Peninsular Campaigns
description: French forces get embroiled in the Iberian Peninsula

title: French invasion of Russia
description: Napoleon's disastrous invasion of Russia

title: Napoleon forced to abdicate
description: Napoleon was forced to abdicate in April 1814 after his unsuccessful invasion of Russia resulted in a broad European alliance against him. In the Treaty of Fontainebleau, Napoleon abdicated the throne and renounced his heirs' claim to any future throne in France. He was then exiled to the island of Elba off the coast of Italy. ​​​

title: Hundred days and Waterloo
description: Napoleon's escapes from Elba and retakes control only to be defeated at Waterloo

title: Paleolithic art
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Humans make art. We do this for many reasons and with whatever technologies are available to us. But can we really know what such ancient images originally meant?

title: France's many revolutions and republics
description: Unlike the American Revolution which fairly cleanly transitioned the United States from British rule to a republic, France's process of democratization was much longer and more painful.  This tutorial gives a scaffold of that (and gives some context for the book/musical/movie "Les Miserables").

title: Beginning of World War I
description: Called the Great War (before World War II came about), World War I was the bloody wake-up call that humanity was entering into a new stage of civilization.  WWI was the defining conflict that took Europe from 19th Century Imperial states, which saw heroism in war, into its more modern form.  Unfortunately, it had to go through World War II as well - which some would argue was due to imbalances created by World War I.

title: Les Miserables and France's many revolutions
description: Overview of early 19th century French history and context for Les Miserables

title: Neolithic art
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The Neolithic Revolution was the most important development in human history. The way we live today—settled in cities, protected by laws, eating food from farms—dates from approximately 10,000 years ago.

title: German and Italian Empires in 1914
description: Italian and German Empires in 1914. Tsingtao beer.

title: Haitian Revolution
description:
Yes, you are right. Haiti is not in Europe.  We put the tutorial here because it was a French colony and its own revolution is closely linked to that of France's.

Possibly one of the saddest histories that a nation can have, this tutorial tries to give as much context as possible for the birth of Haiti.

title: Causes of World War I
description: Test your understanding of what caused World War I.

title: Volume of a rectangular prism
description: Volume measures how much 3-dimensional "space" an object takes up.  We'll see in this tutorial that it is an extension of length (1-D) or area (2-D) to three dimensions!

title: Aegean
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. 19th century archaeologists sought evidence for Homer's epic poems. Instead they uncovered bronze-age art of the Cyclades, the Minoans, and the Mycenaeans.

title: Ancient Greece
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Ancient Greek art was collected in ancient Rome, studied during the Renaissance and formalized in the 19th century. It is the most influential art ever made.

title: Fractions on the number line
description: Learn to identify fractions on a number line.

title: Nabataean
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The Siq is a canyon leading to Petra, the greatest city of the Nabataeans, a people who occupied the area from Sinai to northern Arabia and southern Syria.

title: Western and Eastern fronts of World War I
description: This tutorial goes into some detail to describe the tactics and battles of the two major fronts of World War I--the Western Front and the Eastern Front.

title: Schlieffen Plan and the First Battle of the Marne
Alliances leading to World War I
description: There are a number of European alliances that contributed to the broad scope of World War I. Prominent among these are the 1839 Treaty of London, which promised that the United Kingdom would protect Belgium's neutrality, the 1879 Dual Alliance treaty between Germany and Austria-Hungary to protect each other in the event of Russian attack, the 1892 Franco-Russian Military Convention that promised mutual assistance in the face of attack, the Triple Entente linking the United Kingdom and France (and later Italy), and the Triple Alliance linking Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy (at first).

title: Haitian Revolution (Part 1)
description: Slaves rebel in Saint-Domingue (Haiti).  Rise of Toussaint L'Ouverture.

title: Perimeter
description: Have you ever wondered how much fencing you need to surround a plot of land?  No?  Well, you should still go through this tutorial just in case.  You'll learn all about how to think about and calculate perimeter--essentially the length of the boundary of a figure.

title: Language and religion of the former Yugoslavia
description: Primer on the differences of language and religion that helped to propel World War I.

title: Haitian Revolution (Part 2)
description: Dessalines takes on Leclerc and Rochambeau

title: Assassination of Franz Ferdinand
description: Gavrilo Princip assassinated Austro-Hungarian Archduke Franz Ferdinand, setting off World War I.

title: Latin American independence
description: From the late 1700s through the mid 1800s, most of North and South America achieves independence from European colonial powers. Possible catalyst include the ideas of the Enlightenment from the early 1700s, and the turmoil in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries (French Revolution, Napoleonic Wars, etc.). You also have the emergence of revolutionary figures like Simon Bolivar.

title: Imperialism
description: As nations begin to industrialize, their desire for raw materials and markets in which to sell their products grows. In the 19th century, this is one of the factors that motivates imperialist tendencies (especially among Western European powers).

title: Other fronts of World War I
description: Contrary to what some history books and movies would have you believe, World War I was not just fought on the Western and/or Eastern fronts.  Because of the empires involved, it was a truly global conflict.  This tutorial will cover some of the campaigns that your history book might not (but are important to understanding the War).

title: Fractions intro
description: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

title: Serbian losses in World War I
Italy backs out of Triple Alliance
Ancient Near East
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Ancient Near Eastern cultures established the first cities, the earliest code of laws, and the oldest known writing which was used, not for poetry, but for bookkeeping.

title: Italian front in World War I
Ancient Egypt
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The art of the ancient Egyptians was (for the most part) never meant to be seen by the living—it was meant to benefit the dead in the afterlife.

title: Etruscan
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Before Rome, the Etruscan civilization ruled much what is now Italy. The Etruscans left fine metalwork, elaborate tombs and a deep mark on ancient Roman culture.

title: Comparing the Eastern and Western fronts in WWI
Ancient Rome
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The brilliance of ancient Roman art can be seen in the wall paintings of Pompeii, the massive ambition of the Colosseum, and the daring engineering of the Pantheon.

title: Palmyra
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Palmyra, an ancient caravan city in the Syrian Desert, is renowned for its monumental architecture and colonnaded streets, as well as for its distinctive tower tombs. The ancient city and its material culture incorporated elements from Greek, Roman, and Near Eastern cultures and the city itself existed at a key point of connectivity where the spheres of the Mediterranean, Persian, and Near Eastern world overlapped.

title: Equivalent fractions
description: Learn how to find equivalent fractions visually and by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number.

title: Battles of Verdun, Somme and the Hindenburg Line
Judaism and art
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Judaism is an ancient monotheistic religion with a focus on sacred texts rather than sacred images, making its art an especially interesting area of study.

title: Closing stages of World War I
Intro to decimals
description: What are decimal numbers? How are they like fractions?

title: Eastern and Western fronts of World War I
A beginner's guide to medieval Europe
description: The Middle Ages lasted 1000 years. Learn how manuscripts were made, how medieval calendars worked, and how Christ's life was represented.

title: Blockades and American entry
description:
Naval blockades in World War I to starve enemy nation of trade.

Contrary to what many think, American entry into WWI was not due purely to the sinking of the Lusitania.  Learn more about what caused the United States to play its first major direct role in a European conflict.

title: Books and the dissemination of knowledge in medieval Europe
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Before the invention of print, books were written by hand and made at the request of a reader. Because each book was unique, they can tell us about how people consumed knowledge and interacted with it.

title: Early Christian
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Persecutions of Christians ended in Rome with Emperor Constantine. 4th century churches, tombs and catacombs decorated with Christian imagery can still be visited.

title: Byzantine
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Constantinople (now Istanbul) was the capital of the late Roman empire, but its ethereal mosaics, ivories, and metalwork often depart from classical naturalism.

title: Wilson's war message to Congress -- April 2, 1917
description: Read Wilson's appeal for the United States to enter World War I.

title: Early medieval
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. In the fifth century C.E., people from tribes called Angles, Saxons and Jutes left their homelands in northern Europe to look for a new home. They knew that the Romans had recently left the green land of Britain unguarded, so they sailed across the channel in small wooden boats. The Britons did not give in without a fight, but after many years the invaders managed to overcome them and were to rule for over 500 years.

title: 1917 speech by Senator George Norris in opposition to American entry
Comparing fractions
description: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.

title: Carolingian
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Charlemagne, King of the Franks and later Holy Roman Emperor, instigated a cultural revival known as the Carolingian Renaissance that continues to impact the way European languages are written, the structure of modern law and the very notion of Europe itself.

title: Ottonian
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Otto I (who became emperor in 962) lends his name to the “Ottonian” period. He forged an important alliance with the Pope, which allowed him to be crowned the first official Holy Roman Emperor since 924.

title: World War I shapes the Middle East
description: The Middle East is a center of cultures, religions, and, unfortunately, conflict in our modern world.  This tutorial takes us from a declining Ottoman Empire to the modern Middle East which is still the center of many religions, cultures and conflicts.

title: Theodor Herzl and the birth of political Zionism
Romanesque
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Visogoths, Ostrogoths, and Vikings, oh my! Western Europe was not a peaceful place during the 600 years after the fall of the Roman Empire. Western Europe (what is now Italy, France, Spain, England, etc.) had been repeatedly invaded. The result was a fractured feudal society with little stability and less economic growth.
