It was only in the 11th century that everything began to change. Peace and prosperity allow for travel and for the widespread construction of large buildings. The faithful set out on pilgrimages in great numbers to visit holy relics in churches across Europe. This meant that ideas and styles also traveled, towns grew and churches were built and enlarged. These were, with rare exceptions, the first large structures to be built in the west since the fall of the Romans so many centuries before. We call the period Romanesque (Roman-like) because the masons of this period looked back to the architecture of ancient Rome.

title: Decimals on the number line
description: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

title: الزاوية المركزيّة والزاوية المحيطيّة والعلاقة بينهما
نظريّة (مبرهنة) تالس وعكسها واستعمالها في حل المسائل
استنتاج وإثبات بالبرهان لنظريّات وقوانين تتعلّق بالشكل الرباعي الدائري
Gothic
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. No, we’re not talking about the dark subculture we know as Goth! We’re talking about the style of art and architecture In Europe from the 1100s to the beginnings of the Renaissance at about 1400. Hopefully by the end of this tutorial when someone says Gothic, you’ll think of enormous stained-glass windows in churches whose vaulted ceilings reach toward heaven and not black clothing and dark eyeliner!

title: The Middle East during and after WWI
description: Check your understanding of the role of World War I in shaping the Middle East.

title: Aftermath of World War I
description:
World war I (or the Great War) was a defining event for the 20th Century.  It marked the end (or beginning of the end) of centuries-old empires and the dawn-of newly independent states based on ethnic and linguistic commonality.   It didn't just change the face of Europe, it changed the face of the world.

From the Paris Peace Conference and Treaty of Versailles, we'll see how the end of World War I may have been just the set up for even more conflict in Europe and the world.

title: Intro to negative numbers
description: What are negative numbers? When do we use them? Where do we find them on the number line? Let's learn what happens in the world below zero!

title: Common denominators
description: Using our knowledge of equivalent fractions, let's rewrite fractions to have the same denominator.

title: Rounding decimals
description: Learn how to round decimal numbers to specific place values. For example, round 3.14159 to the nearest hundredth as 3.14.

title: Order negative numbers
description: We all know that 6 is bigger than 4, but is -6 bigger than -4? This tutorial is designed to help you compare negative numbers.

title: Decomposing fractions
description: See that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.

title: Rise of Hitler and the Nazis
description: How did the National Socialists (Nazis) go from being a tiny, marginal party in the early 1920s to having full control of Germany and catalyzing World War II?  Who was Hitler and what was his philosophy and how did he come to power?

title: Comparing decimals
description: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!

title: Number opposites
description: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract fractions. This is an introductory tutorial, so the fractions you add and subtract have the same denominators.

title: Adding decimals
description: Honestly, once you remember one very important rule, the rest of adding and subtracting decimals is a snap. That rule is to be sure and align your decimals first. In this tutorial, you'll get a chance to practice this with us and become fluent adding decimals. We'll tackle subtracting decimals in the next tutorial.

title: Rise of Mussolini and Fascism
description:
The word "Fascist" is now a pejorative term ("pejorative" means "negative" or "derogatory") to describe leaders or states that have absolute control and are aggressively nationalistic.

The terms "fascism" and "fascist", however, were first embraced by Benito Mussolini in Italy in the 1920s and 1930s to describe their party and policies (that were absolutist and aggressively nationalistic).  

This tutorial described Mussolini and the Fascists' rapid rise to power and the influence it had on the rest of the world (including providing a model for Hitler in Germany).

title: Absolute value
description: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

title: Rewriting decimals as fractions
description: Learn how to rewrite decimals as fractions.

title: Mixed numbers
description: Learn how to write improper fractions as mixed numbers (and mixed numbers as improper fractions).

title: Fascism and Mussolini
description: Questions about Mussolini and Fascism during the 1920s and 1930s

title: Overview of Chinese history 1911-1949
description: The early 1900s marked the end of thousands of years of dynastic imperial rule in China.  It also marked the beginning of a complex period of fragmentation, civil war and fending off Japanese imperial ambitions.  This tutorial covers everything from the establishment of the Republic of China by Sun Yat-sen to the Warlord Era to the Chinese Civil War between the Chiang Kai-Shek led Kuomintang and the Communists led by Mao Zedong.

title: Overview of World War II
description: World War II was the bloodiest conflict in human history.    Starting with the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937) and the Nazi invasion of Poland (1939) through the eventual Axis power surrenders, this tutorial walks through the major events, year by year, in both the European and Pacific Arenas.

title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract fractions that have different denominators.

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

title: Intro to subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

title: The Cold War
description: The cold war between the United States and the Soviet and their respective allies never involved direct conflict (which might have ended the world).  Instead, it involved posturing, brinksmanship and proxy wars in far-flung regions of the world.

title: Adding and subtracting mixed number with unlike denominators
description: Learn how to add and subtract mixed numbers whose fractional parts have different denominators.

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers
description: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

title: Human rights
description: The 20th century saw the end of traditional imperialism, but also some of the bloodiest events in human history.  In reaction to this, attempts at frameworks have been developed to prevent these types of things from happening in the future?  Will they be successful?

title: Adding and subtracting fractions word problems
description: Practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting fractions.

title: Subtracting decimal
description: Just like with adding decimals, the key to subtracting decimals is aligning the decimal points. Let's practice!

title: Multiplying & dividing negative numbers
description: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

title: A beginner's guide to the art of Islam
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The Taj Mahal, a silk carpet, a Qur‘an; all of these are examples of Islamic art. But what exactly is Islamic art and architecture?

title: Early period
description:
Brought to you by Smarthistory. Early Period (c. 640-900 C.E.)
From the rightfully guided caliphs who succeeded Muhammad,  through the Umayyads' Dome of the Rock and Great Mosque of Damascus, to the decline of Abbasids rule.

title: Multiplying whole numbers and fractions
description: Learn the art of multiplying whole numbers by fractions. See how 3 times 2/3 is the same as 6 times 1/3, which is the same as 6/3.

title: Medieval period
description:
Brought to you by Smarthistory. Medieval Period (c. 900-1517 C.E.)
The Fatimids (909-1171) ruled north Africa, and parts of Syria and the Seljuqs contolled eastern Islamic lands and eventually Iran, Iraq and much of Anatolia.

title: Late period
description:
Brought to you by Smarthistory. Later Period (c. 1517 –1924 C.E.)
The Ottomans, a small Turkic state in Anatolia, emerged as a major military and political force and conquered Constantinople, the Balkans, the Near East, and North Africa.

title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
description: In this tutorial, we practice solving word problems by adding and subtracting decimal numbers.

title: Arts of the Islamic world (quiz)
description: Test your knowledge of the arts of the Islamic world!

title: Coordinate plane
description: We first explored the coordinate plane in the 5th grade, but that was only dealing with positive coordinates.  Now we know all about negative numbers so why not have negative coordinates as well? Let's get cozy with the x and y axis, plotting ordered pairs, quadrants, and reflection points. We got it covered. Sit back, relax, and get ready to groove with us.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.6, 6.NS.C.6b, 6.NS.C.6c, 6.NS.C.8

title: Multiplication as scaling
description: Learn to see multiplication as a way to grow (scale up) and shrink (scale down) other numbers.

title: Multiplying decimals
description: You've already multiplied decimals in the 5th grade. We'll show you some ways to handle slightly more complicated problems. Now you'll become super good at it with a bit more practice!  Common Core Standard: 6.NS.B.3

title: Multiplying fractions
description: Learn how to multiply a fraction by a fraction.

title: Intro to ratios
description: Ratios show up everywhere in life—sports, finance, medicine, cooking, you name it! In this tutorial, we learn what ratios are and how to use them.

title: Multiplying mixed numbers
description: Learn how to multiply mixed numbers.

title: Dividing decimals
description: Learn long division with decimals. Solve problems like 30.24 divided by 0.42.

title: Multiplying fractions word problems
description: Get some practice solving word problems by multiplying fractions.

title: Fractions as division
description: **Spoiler Alert!** The fraction bar and the division symbol are really saying the same thing.

title: Solving ratio problems with graph
description: In this example we'll plot points on the x and y axis to reflect the given ratios.

title: Visualize ratios
description: Use double number lines, ratio tables, and tape diagrams to visualize ratios.

title: Dividing unit fractions and whole numbers
description: Learn how to divide unit fractions by whole numbers. Example: 1/5 ÷ 3 = 1/15.

title: Dividing fractions by fractions
description: Learn how to divide fractions by other fractions.

title: Late Gothic art in Italy
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The art of Giotto and Duccio was once known as primitive, and useful only as a prelude to the Renaissance. However, recent scholarship allows us to study the brilliant artists of Florence and Siena in their own right.

title: Renaissance in Italy: 1400s
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The engineering of Brunelleschi's dome, the naturalism of Donatello’s David, and the humanism of Botticelli’s Birth of Venus each help define the Early Renaissance in Italy.

title: Percent, fraction, decimal conversions
description: Decimals and percents are two ways of expressing the same number. For example, 0.5 and 50% mean the exact same thing. Learn how to convert decimals to percents and vice versa.

title: Absolute value
description: Absolute value is a simple but important property of numbers. Get comfortable with finding the absolute value of numbers and interpreting their meaning.

title: Ordering numeric expressions
description: Ordering numbers expressed as decimals, fractions, and percentages.

title: A beginner's guide to the Art of the Americas
S. America before European colonization
description: A beginner's guide to South America before European colonization

title: Colonial Latin America
description: Art and culture from the European invasion of the Americas to the end of the colonial era with a focus on one of the most remarkable examples of cross cultural influence ever made.

title: British Colonies to the Early Republic
Dependent and independent variables
description: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

title: Art Brut
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory.

title: Renaissance and after in Italy: 1500s
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Michelangelo's Sistine Ceiling, Leonardo’s Last Supper, and Raphael's Stanza frescos shape our understanding of Western culture even today.

title: Intro to variables
description: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

title: Renaissance in Northern Europe: 1400s
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Northern Europe’s wealthy merchants and nobles supported the art of van Eyck, Bosch, Dürer, Bruegel, and Holbein; art that invites us back to their world.

title: Ratio application
description: Expand on ratios by exploring part:part:whole ratios and ratios on the coordinate plane.

title: Dividing fractions word problems
description: Practice solving word problems with fraction division.

title: Renaissance and after in Northern Europe: 1500s
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Discover Grünewald, Bosch, Dürer, Bruegel, Holbein and other extraordinary artists from the Renaissance in England, Germany, Flanders, etc.

title: Substitution & evaluating expressions
description: Learn how to substitute (or "plug in") values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions.

title: Renaissance and after in Spain
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory.

title: Reformation and Counter-Reformation
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Why are there so many Protestant denominations (Baptist, Presbyterian, Pentecostal, etc.)? The early 16th century, a time when the Roman Catholicism was largely unchallenged in Western Europe, holds the answer.

title: Intro to rates
description: Learn about a special type of ratio called a rate. A rate is the ratio of two measurements that have different units such as 10 kilometers per hour or 12 hot dogs per minute!

title: Baroque art
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Stone becomes flesh and ceilings dissolve into the infinity of heaven—artists such as Bernini, Caravaggio, Rubens, Velazquez and Rembrandt were masters of drama and illusion.

title: Rococo
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Overgrown gardens heavy with the scent of roses, palaces and luxury; the artists Watteau, Boucher, and Fragonard typify the aristocratic style known as Rococo.

title: Topic D: Lessons 25-28: Modeling with exponential functions
Topic D: Equations for circles and their tangents
يستخدم الاحتمال المشروط و الحوادث المستقلة في حل مسائل حياتية
Exponents
description:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

title: Neo-Classicism
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Jacques Louis David invented a style reflecting Enlightenment ideas by looking back to ancient art. He became a revolutionary and 1st painter to Napoleon.

title: Exponentiation warmup
description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

title: British art in the 18th century
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Britain and America were at war but shared a common artistic tradition. From Hogarth’s biting satire to Jefferson’s Monticello—here is invention, wit, nobility.

title: Expression value intuition
description: Explore how the value of an algebraic expression changes as the value of its variable changes.

title: Multiple rates word problem
description: Sometimes you'll need to solve for multiple parts of the equation before getting at the answer. Here we solve for average speed, but first we have to determine total distance and total time.

title: Constructing numeric expressions
description: Let's construct and interpret expressions from word problems.  We can also think about what the effects of parentheses are.

title: Negative numbers
description: Understanding and operating with negative numbers is key in algebra.  This tutorial will make sure that you have the basics down!

title: Finding average speed or rate
description: Using the formula for finding distance we can determine Usian Bolt's average speed, or rate, when he broke the world record in 2009 in the 100m. Watch.

title: Speed translation
description: Sal converts feet to inches to help solve a rate problem.

title: Evaluating expressions word problems
description: Learn how to plug in values to evaluate real-world expressions.

title: Intro to percents
description: Percent literally means "per cent" or "per hundred". Learn how to rewrite fractions as percents and vice versa.

title: Square roots
description:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!

title: Understanding square roots
description: Learn how square root means what number multiplied by itself will result in the given number.

title: Writing algebraic expressions introduction
description: Learn the basics of writing expressions with variables.

title: Simplifying a cube root
description: Simplifying Radical Expressions1

title: Percent word problems
description: Learn how to solve a variety of word problems involving percentages.

title: Simplifying square roots
description: Roots are nice, but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So, for example, instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer, like √20? Still, we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5, which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Simplify square roots
description: For example, simplify √18 as 3√2.

title: Absolute value and number lines
description: One easy way to think of absolute value is the distance it is from zero. To do that, a number line comes in handy. Watch and learn.

title: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems
description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) to model real-world situations.

title: Cube roots
description: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that, when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!

title: Exponents
description:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

title: Cube root of a non-perfect cube
Exponent example 1
description: Sal explains the difference between 5 × 3 and 5 to the third power

title: Algebraic equations basics
description: Explore what it means for equations with variables (algebraic equations) to be solved.

title: Exponent properties
description:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.

title: Writing fractions as decimals review
description: Review writing fractions as decimals, and try some practice problems.

title: Percent problems
description: Learn how to solve percent problems like these: What is 80% of 25? Three is what percent of four?

title: One-step equations intuition
description: A high-level, conceptual walk-through of what an equation represents and why we do the same thing to both sides of it

title: Identifying percent amount and base
description: Sal identifies the percent, amount, and base in a percent problem.

title: Powers of products & quotients (structured practice)
description: Rewrite expressions that involve powers of products and quotients. Expressions are in ascending difficulty.

title: Negative exponents
description:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.

title: Square roots
description: A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical. What is it? How does it relate to exponents? Learn all about square roots in this tutorial.

title: Percent word problem: 78 is 15% of what number?
description: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

title: Percent word problem: penguins
description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.

title: Simplifying square roots of fractions
description: Sal rewrites √(1/200) as 1/(10*√2) and as √2/20.

title: Growing by a percentage
description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.

title: One-step multiplication and division equations
description: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

title: Simplifying square-root expressions: no variables
description: Sal simplifies sums and products of square roots. For example, he simplifies -√40+√90 as √10.

title: Simplify square-roots (variables)
description: Simplify square roots that contain variables in them, like √(8x³)

title: Properties of exponents challenge (integer exponents)
description: A quiz that covers all exponent properties using integer exponents.

title: Order of operations
description: In this tutorial, we learn the "order of operations" to evaluate more complex expressions involving exponents, parentheses, multiplication and division, and addition and subtraction.

title: Inequality word problem: one variable
description: This time we're creating a variable to represent a number, and then writing an inequality. We're building on our knowledge.

title: N. America before European colonization
description: Learn about the the early peoples and places in the Americas from Alaska to Panama

title: Two-step equations intro
description: Learn how to solve equations like 2x+7=13 and 3(x+4)=3, which can be solved in two steps.

title: Writing & solving proportions
description: Learn how to write proportions and how to solve proportions.

title: Native American art after 1600
description: Native societies across North American developed diverse material cultures that reflect the character of their regions and respond to the universal issues of human and spiritual existence.

title: Operations with decimals
description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals.

title: Scientific notation
description:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!

title: Introduction to scientific notation
description: Introduction to scientific notation. An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.

title: Scientific notation examples
description: More scientific notation examples

title: One-step equation word problems
description: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

title: Fractions
description: This tutorial will help to review arithmetic with fractions

title: Constant of proportionality
description: Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.

title: Orders of magnitude
description: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.

title: One-step equations review
description: A one-step equation is an algebraic equation you can solve in only one step. You've solved the equation when you get the variable by itself, with no numbers in front of it, on one side of the equal sign.

title: Inequalities: Greater than and less than basics
description:
Equality is usually a good thing, but the world is not a perfect place.  No matter how hard we try, we can't help but compare one thing to another and realize how unequal they may be.

This tutorial gives you the tools to do these comparisons in the mathematical world (which we call inequalities).  You'll become familiar with the "greater than" and "less than symbols" and learn to use them.

title: Decimals, fractions and percentages
description: Let's review how to convert between fractions, decimals and percentages

title: Computing with scientific notation
description: You already understand what scientific notation is.  Now you'll actually use it to compute values and solve real-world problems.

title: Multiplying in scientific notation example
description: Learn how to solve a multiplication problem using scientific notation: (9.1 * 10^6)(3.2 * 10^-5)

title: Inequality word problems
description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems.

title: Identifying proportional relationships
description: Learn how to tell whether two quantities are proportional by thinking about equivalent ratios and drawing graphs.

title: Multiple units word problem: road trip
description: Sal solves a word problem where he finds the cost of gas in a road trip given the car's fuel efficiency, length of the trip, and price of gas.

title: Multiple units word problems
description: Solve word problems that contain multiple quantities that are measured in different units.

title: Multiplying decimals example
description: To multiply decimals, first multiply as if there is no decimal. Next, count the number of digits after the decimal in each factor. Finally, put the same number of digits behind the decimal in the product. For example, if we multiply 7.61✕9.2, we will have 3 digits behind the decimal in our product because there are 3 digits behind the decimals in the factors.

title: Introduction to variables
description: Wait, why are we using letters in math? How can an 'x' represent a number? What number is it? This tutorial is great if you're just beginning to delve into the world of variables and expressions.

title: Introduction—Becoming Modern
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory.

title: Systems of equations with substitution: potato chips
description:
To solve a system of equations using substitution...
1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations, e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation, e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it, and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Strings
description: The largest group within the orchestra is comprised of instruments that produce sound from vibrating strings. The vibrations – resulting from the strings being played by a bow, or being plucked with the fingers – resonate within the body of each instrument. The violin, viola, cello and contrabass are all primary played with a bow. The harp is  plucked and stroked with the hands. Principals from the All-Star Orchestra introduce the special qualities and histories of each instrument.

title: African art, an introduction
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Find here a brief introduction to the peoples and cultures of Africa.

title: Harp: Interview and demonstration with principal Nancy Allen
Robert Schumann: Symphony No. 3, "Rhenish".  Analysis by Gerard Schwarz (part 5)
description: Watch full performance here

title: East Africa and the Horn of Africa
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. East Africa is a huge region with Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia and Somalia to the north, Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi to the south and the Indian Ocean Islands of Comoros, Mauritius, Seychelles, Réunion and Mayotte.

title: Violin: Interview and demonstration with concertmaster David Kim
Johannes Brahms: Academic Festival Overture
description: Although Johannes Brahms never went to a university, he was offered a PhD from the University of Breslau, but he to receive this he had to compose a work for the school. This became the Academic Festival Overture, described by Brahms as a cheerful potpourri of student songs. The overture has the largest orchestration of any of Brahms’ works, and is among his most charming and optimistic pieces.

title: Clarinet: Interview and demonstration with principal Jon Manasse

title: Interpreting linear functions and equations
description: Solve word problems where you need to answer a question about a real-world relationship based on its mathematical model.

title: The building blocks of Keynesian analysis
description: What is the Keynesian perspective anyway?

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Identifying which graph represents a given exponential function.

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

title: West Africa
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. West Africa includes the Cape Verde Islands, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Ivory Coast, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, the island of Saint Helena, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Sao Tome/Principe and Togo.

title: Scientific notation intro
description: Scientists and engineers often deal with super huge numbers like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 and super small numbers like 0.0000000000532. How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits? The answer to both questions: scientific notation.

title: Viola: Interview and demonstration with principal Rebecca Young
Johannes Brahms: "Academic Festival Overture", analysis by Gerard Schwarz
description: Watch the full performance here

title: North Africa
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. This region includes Algeria, Chad, Egypt, Libya,  Morocco, Sudan, Tunisia, and the Canary and Madeira Islands.

title: Cello: Interview and demonstration with principal Jerry Grossman
Antonín Dvořák: Symphony No. 9 "From the New World"
description: Inspired by American dreams and legends, Antonin Dvořák created some of his greatest works while living in the United States, above all the “New World” Symphony. Music Director Gerard Schwarz and Dvořák expert Joseph Horowitz delve into the music, and illuminate the multiple stories and influences – Native American, African-American and Czech –that Dvořák transformed in his most famous work.

title: Southern Africa
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Southern Africa includes Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Central Africa
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. Central Africa includes Angola, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, and  the island groups São Tomé and Príncipe.

title: Woodwinds
description: This family of instruments is situated in the middle of the orchestra, and is comprised of three groups: the flutes (flutes, piccolo), single reeds (clarinets, bass-clarinet), and double reeds (oboe, English horn, bassoons, contra-bassoon) Watch and listen as principal players of the All-Star Orchestra demonstrate their instruments and tell about their musical lives.

title: Gustav Mahler: Symphony No. 2 – 1st Movement
description: Following the heroic birth of his first symphony, “The Titan,” in 1889, Gustav Mahler began his next symphony with the question “Is there life after death?” The opening movement of Symphony #2 represents mystical “funerary rites.” The music evokes awe of the unknown, and the hope of resurrection. Music Director Gerard Schwarz and Mahler expert Gilbert Kaplan offer two perspectives of this powerful work.

title: Adding polynomials
description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

Igor Stravinsky: Suite from The Firebird
description: The magical world of Russian folklore comes to life as Music Director Gerard Schwarz tells the story of The Firebird ballet, and looks into the music of Igor Stravinsky's thrilling musical score that was commissioned by the legendary impresario Serge Diaghilev and his Ballets Russes.

title: Discovering Stravinsky's "Firebird" : The story and the music

title: Maurice Ravel: Suite No. 2 from Daphnis et Chloe
description: Analysis by Gerard Schwarz. A love story from ancient Greek mythology inspired the creation of an epic ballet in 1912. French composer Maurice Ravel expanded the possibilities of orchestral color and texture in his remarkable score. Music Director Gerard Schwarz explores the history and musical structure of this landmark work of musical Impressionism.

title: English Horn: Interview and demonstration with Pedro Diaz
Maurice Ravel: "Daphnis et Chloé", analysis by Gerard Schwarz
description: Watch full performance here

title: Lapita Culture
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory.

title: Adding and subtracting polynomials review
description: Adding and subtracting polynomials is all about combining like terms. In this article, we review some examples and give you a chance for you to practice the skill yourself.

title: Brass
description: Each of the instruments in this family are made to sound by the vibrations of the player's lips combined with a steady stream of breath. Learn from the All-Star Orchestra players themselves about the special attributes of the trumpet, French horn, trombone, bass trombone and tuba.

title: Dmitri Shostakovich: Symphony No. 5
description: Music has sometimes reflected, and at other times challenged repressive ideologies.  Dmitri Shostakovich abandoned the premiere of his daring 4th symphony in 1935 for fear of reprisals from the Soviet government. Then he composed his triumphant 5th Symphony in 1937, and Stalin was pleased.  To this day the 5th is Shostakovich’s most popular symphony. What is its message?  What does “political music” mean today?

title: Polynesia
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. The islands of the eastern Pacific are known as Polynesia, from the Greek for "many islands."  Set within a triangle formed by Aotearoa (New Zealand) in the south, Hawaii to the north and Rapa Nui (Easter Island) in the east, the Polynesian islands are dotted across the vast eastern Pacific Ocean. Though small and separated by thousands of miles, they share similar environments and were settled by people with a common cultural heritage. The western Polynesian islands of Fiji and Tonga were settled approximately 3,000 years ago, whilst New Zealand was settled as recently as 1200 C.E.

title: Multiplying binomials
description: Learn how to multiply monomials and binomials.

title: French Horn: Interview and demonstration with principal John Cerminaro
Equation practice with segment addition
description: Given an information about the lengths of line segments, form and solve an equation in order to find the lengths of the segments.

title: Equation practice with midpoints
description: Given an information about the distance of a segment's midpoint from its endpoints, Sal forms and solves an equation in order to find the length of the segment.

title: Equation practice with midpoints
description: Given information about the distance of a segment's midpoint from its endpoints, form and solve an equation in order to find the length of the segment.

title: David Stock: Blast!
description: The composer says: "I knew what kind of piece this needed to be, and I knew I wanted it to be loud, and I knew I wanted it to be fun, so that's how it came to be “Blast!", and I had a blast writing it!”

title: Pythagorean theorem
description: Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

title: Factoring polynomials by taking a common factor
description: Learn how to factor a common factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, factor 6x²+10x as 2x(3x+5).

title: Production possibilities curve
description: Tradeoffs for a hunter-gatherer and the production possibilities curve, and the notion of "ceteris paribus" (which means "everything else held equal").

title: Value added approach to calculating GDP
description: In this video we learn how a nation's GDP can be calculated by summing up the value added by all the intermediate producers in a nation.

title: Melanesia
description: Brought to you by Smarthistory. To the north and east of Australia lie the islands known as Melanesia. These islands form one of the most culturally complex regions of the entire world, with 1,293 languages spoken across the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, New Caledonia and the island of New Guinea (politically divided into Indonesia’s West Papua Province and the nation of Papua New Guinea). It is also a region of great antiquity.  New Guinea has been settled for around 45,000 years, the Solomon Islands for 35,000 years, and Vanuatu and New Caledonia for about 4,000.

description: We use the distributive property to multiply monomials by polynomials. For example, 2x(3x+7) = 6x^2+14x. This article provides a brief review of the topic and gives you a couple of practice problems to try on your own.

title: Introduction to Philip Glass' "Harmonium Mountain"
description: Philip Glass is often called the most famous living composer today. His short work, Harmonium Mountain, was conceived in partnership with the visual artist Clifford Ross as the soundtrack for an animated film based on ever-changing images of a mountain in Colorado. This analysis explores connections between the visual and musical arts.

title: Percussion
description: This large family, including timpani, drums, cymbals, xylophones, gongs, bells, and rattles, is comprised of  musical instruments played by striking with the hand or with a stick or beater, or by shaking or rubbing.  The All-Star Orchestra percussion section demonstrates the remarkable variety of sounds that can be produced. Also included in this group are orchestral keyboard instruments like the piano and celesta.

title: Multiply binomials intro
description: Use the distributive property to express the product of two binomials as a single polynomial.

title: Augusta Read Thomas: Of Paradise and Light
description: A leading composer of her generation, Augusta Read Thomas' works have been performed by major orchestras around the world. Here she discusses the compositional process that led to Of Paradise and Light. Music Director Gerard Schwarz joins in the discussion of this transcendent new work.

title: "Of Paradise and Light": The composer and her work
description: Watch the full performance here.

title: Equation practice with vertical angles
description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles, form and solve an equation.

title: Special products of binomials
description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

title: Course materials
description: These syllabi and sample discussion questions are for the use of instructors who are encouraged to build on and adapt them for their own classes. They can also be used by individual learners seeking a pathway through the art history content on Khan Academy akin to an introductory college-level survey course.

title: Bright Sheng: "Black Swan", the composer and his work
description: A lovely Intermezzo for piano by Johannes Brahms (1833-1897) inspired contemporary composer Bright Sheng to orchestrate this short work in his own style. Sheng, who served as composer in residence for the New York City Ballet, has titled this musical transformation “Black Swan."

title: Special products of the form (x+a)(x-a)
description: Sal introduces difference of squares expressions. For example, (x+3)(x-3) is expanded as x²-9.

title: Squaring binomials of the form (x+a)²
description: Sal introduces perfect square expressions. For example, (x+7)² is expanded as x²+14x+49.

title: Richard Danielpour: Piano Concerto No. 4, Movement III
description: “A Hero’s Journey” is the title given by  Richard Danielpour to this dynamic movement from his Fourth Piano Concerto. In this analysis the composer describes the inspiration for his music, with comments by the soloist  Xiayin Wang and Music Director Gerard Schwarz.

title: Triangle angles
description: Do the angles in a triangle always add up to the same thing?  Would I ask it if they didn't?  What do we know about the angles of a triangle if two of the sides are congruent (an isosceles triangle) or all three are congruent (an equilateral)?  This tutorial is the place to find out.

title: Special products of binomials intro
description: Find perfect squares of the forms (x+a)² and (x-a)², and differences of squares of the form (x+a)(x-a).

title: Scarcity
description: Welcome to Economics! In this lesson we'll define Economic and introduce some of the fundamental tools and perspectives economists use to understand the world around us!

title: Binomial special products review
description: A review of the difference of squares pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a^2-b^2, as well as other common patterns encountered while multiplying binomials, such as (a+b)^2=a^2+2ab+b^2.

title: "Blast!": Composer and his work
description: Watch the full performance here

title: Joseph Schwantner: The Poet's Hour
description: This piece was inspired by the transcendental writings of Thoreau, and the New England landscape. The composer says: "There are mornings when the world seems to begin, it is a 'new beyond' where memory need not go, it’s the poet’s hour. You get up early in the morning, and it becomes an extraordinary invigorating environment in which to lead an artist's life.”

title: Factoring binomials: common factor

title: Triangle similarity intro
description: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

title: Intro to triangle similarity
description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar, and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Factoring polynomials: common binomial factor
description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.

title: Opportunity cost and the Production Possibilities Curve
description: Learn how the production possibilities curve is used to illustrate scarcity, opportunity costs, and economic growth in this lesson.

title: Triangle similarity postulates/criteria

title: Factor polynomials: common factor

title: Determine similar triangles: AA
description: Given two triangles with some of their angle measures, determine whether the triangles are similar or not.

title: Factoring by common factor review
description: The expression 6m+15 can be factored into 3(2m+5) using the distributive property. More complex expressions like 44k^5-66k^4 can be factored in much the same way. This article provides a couple of examples and gives you a chance to try it yourself.

title: Circular flow of income and expenditures

title: Determining similar triangles

title: PPCs for increasing, decreasing and constant opportunity cost
description: Production possibility curves for increasing, decreasing and constant opportunity cost.

title: Factoring quadratics as (x+a)(x+b)
description: Sal factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Parsing gross domestic product
description: Understanding what GDP does and doesn't measure.

title: Determine similar triangles: SSS

title: More on final and intermediate GDP contributions
description: What happens when a good is not finished in a period

title: Production Possibilities Curve as a model of a country's economy
description: In this video Sal explains how the production possibilities curve model can be used to illustrate changes in a country's actual and potential level of output. Concepts covered include efficiency, inefficiency, economic growth and contraction and recession.

title: Factoring quadratics: leading coefficient = 1
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions as the product of two linear binomials. For example, x²+5x+6=(x+2)(x+3).

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

title: Investment and consumption
description: Difference between every day and economic notions of investment and consumption

title: Solve similar triangles (basic)
description: Given two similar triangles and some of their side lengths, find a missing side length.

title: Income and expenditure views of GDP
description: Looking at a simple model of an economy

title: Comparative advantage and the gains from trade
description: When economies specialize based on comparative advantage and trade, they can both benefit. Explore the concepts of comparative advantage, absolute advantage, specialization, and the terms of trade in this lesson.

title: Factoring quadratics intro
description: Factor quadratics of the form x²+bx+c.

title: Comparative advantage, specialization, and gains from trade
description: This video explores how two parties can get better outcomes by specializing in their comparative advantage and trading.

title: Components of GDP
description: Understanding the components of the expenditure view of GDP. Consumption, investment, government spending and net exports

title: Solving similar triangles: same side plays different roles
description: Sal finds a missing side length in a problem where the same side plays different roles in two similar triangles.

title: Factoring simple quadratics review
description: Factoring quadratics is very similar to multiplying binomials, just going the other way. For example, x^2+3x+2 factors to (x+1)(x+2) because (x+1)(x+2) multiplies to x^2+3x+2. This article reviews the basics of how to factor quadratics into the product of two binomials.

title: Comparative advantage and absolute advantage
description: Trade benefits both agents when each specializes in what they have a comparative advantage in producing and trading with another agent who has a comparative advantage in something else. The gains from trade occur based on comparative advantage, not absolute advantage.

title: Expenditure approach to calculating GDP examples
description: Learn about how purchases of different things would impact GDP.

title: Factoring quadratics 2
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x²+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

title: Opportunity cost and comparative advantage using an output table
description: In this video, we use the PPCs for two different countries that each produce two goods in order to create an output table based on the data in the graph. We then use the output table to determine the opportunity costs of producing each good. Finally, we determine which country as a comparative advantage in each good.

title: Lesson summary: The circular flow and GDP
Terms of trade and the gains from trade
description: In this video, we explore how we can use opportunity costs to determine who has comparative advantage in producing a good. By specializing in the production of a good that a country has comparative advantage in, and trading for the other good, both countries have the potential to benefit from the exchange. We can also figure out a trading price (also known as the "terms of trade") which would make both countries willing to trade.

title: The circular flow model and GDP
description: Questions on the circular flow model and GDP

title: Input approach to determining comparative advantage
description: In this video, we take a slightly different approach to determining comparative advantage because we are given data in a slightly different way. Rather than knowing how much of two goods can be produced in a day, we know how much of a resources (in this case labor) is needed to produce one unit of a good.

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Sal factors 4y^2+4y-15 as (2y-3)(2y+5) by grouping.

title: About "Seeing America"
description: Seeing America is a multimedia learning resource for American history that makes key works of art accessible for the American History and Socials Studies student.

title: When there aren't gains from trade
description: In a previous lesson we learned that there is the potential for two countries to gain from trade. But it is also possible that there might not be the potential to gain from trade. In this video, we explore the circumstance that would lead to there being no gains from trade.

title: Limitations of GDP
description: GDP is the most commonly used measure of output, but it leaves some things out. Learn about the limitations of GDP in this video.

title: Comparative advantage worked example
description: Comparative advantage worked example. Type of question you would see on an AP economics exam.

title: Factor quadratics by grouping
description: Factor quadratics of the form ax²+bx+c.

description:
Cole feared for the American landscape as his country expanded westward.

Thomas Cole, The Hunter’s Return, 1845, oil on canvas (Amon Carter Museum of American Art). Speakers: Dr. Maggie Adler, Curator, Amon Carter Museum of American Art and Dr. Beth Harris

title: Unemployment rate primer
description: How the unemployment rate is calculated
